item.title: Best and Worst Moments From Trump’s State of the Union Address
item.content:encoded: Eight Opinion writers weigh in on the speech.

item.title: Maurene Comey, a Prosecutor in Epstein Case, Joins New York Law Firm
item.content:encoded: Maurene Comey is joining Patterson Belknap Webb & Tyler. She was abruptly fired by the Trump administration last year after a career as a top federal prosecutor.

item.title: Surgeon General Nominee Is Pressed on Vaccine Stance in Confirmation Hearing
item.content:encoded: Dr. Casey Means, a wellness influencer and critic of mainstream medicine, is appearing before a Senate committee.

item.title: Corporate America’s Growing Quest for Tariff Refunds
item.content:encoded: Thousands of companies are expected to follow FedEx in suing the government to recoup levy payments, after the Supreme Court overturned the tariffs.

item.title: How the UK Could Remove Former Prince Andrew From the Royal Line of Succession
item.content:encoded: Despite his connections with the sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, the former prince is eighth in line to the British throne. That could change.

item.title: Delroy Lindo on ‘Sinners,’ the Oscars and the Power of Affirmation
item.content:encoded: In a career of standout performances and dispiriting lows, Lindo, 73, has held firm to his goal: “I want to be respected for my work.”

item.title: Germany’s Leader Merz Delivers a Blunt Warning to China on Trade
item.content:encoded: Chancellor Friedrich Merz laid out his complaints in a frank message to his hosts on a trip to Beijing that China had designed to showcase their relationship.

item.title: Inside Nicolás Maduro’s Last Days as Venezuela’s Leader
item.content:encoded: The Venezuelan leader overestimated his strength and misread his exchange with President Trump in the decisive weeks before his capture by U.S. forces.

item.title: Blaming Tariffs, Aston Martin to Trim 20% of Its Work Force
item.content:encoded: The luxury automaker said losses for 2025 had increased from the year before, as tariffs and geopolitical uncertainty take a toll on its operations.

item.title: Trump Puts On a Show, Casting Democrats as the Villains
item.content:encoded: On the defensive over the economy and with the midterms approaching, President Trump made clear that his political strategy is to paint Democrats as unpatriotic and ‘crazy.’

item.title: Hunters and Veterans Are Fighting Trump’s Pick to Oversee Public Lands
item.content:encoded: Steve Pearce, President Trump’s nominee to lead the Bureau of Land Management, is set to face a Senate hearing on Wednesday.

item.title: 6 Takeaways From Trump’s State of the Union
item.content:encoded: In an address that was heavy on theatrics, President Trump lashed out at Democrats as “crazy” and unpatriotic.

item.title: Pope Leo to Visit Africa, Signaling Continent’s Importance to Catholicism
item.content:encoded: The number of Roman Catholics is growing faster in Africa than anywhere else, according to the Vatican.

item.title: What Trump Did (and Didn’t) Say in the State of the Union Speech
item.content:encoded: The president boasted about a strong economy in his State of the Union address. But he spent less time on a potential weakness, affordability.

item.title: A Seasoned French Museum Chief Takes Over a Louvre in Crisis
item.content:encoded: Christophe Leribault, who runs the Palace of Versailles, will replace Laurence des Cars, who resigned months after an audacious jewel heist.

item.title: How Trump’s Economic Pitch at the State of the Union Echoes Biden’s
item.content:encoded: With the midterms approaching and polls showing unease about the economy, some of President Trump’s arguments about its strength sounded eerily like those of his predecessor.

item.title: Key Moments from Trump’s State of the Union, and a $1 Million Reward in the Guthrie Case
item.content:encoded: Plus, how kids are getting around phone-free classroom rules.

item.title: Thanks, Ukrainians Say, but Please Stop Calling Us Resilient
item.content:encoded: Ukraine must project strength to secure continued Western support. But its people want the world to know they are not superhuman.

item.title: Bleak Research Report Stokes A.I. Debate on Wall St.
item.content:encoded: In a widely circulated note, Citrini Research painted a dire picture of job losses and stock market sell-offs, though many analysts and economists questioned its conclusions.

item.title: Bleak Research Report Stokes A.I. Debate on Wall St.
item.content:encoded: In a widely circulated note, Citrini Research painted a dire picture of job losses and stock market sell-offs, though many analysts and economists questioned its conclusions.

item.title: Online Accusations in Guthrie Abduction Leave One Family ‘Scared Numb’
item.content:encoded: A fifth-grade teacher and his principal wife hid in their bedroom as dozens of people who believed he might be a kidnapper appeared on their suburban street.

item.title: From the French Riviera to Kyoto, Japan, 5 New Luxury Hotels
item.content:encoded: From palatial to contemporary to luxuriously rustic, this collection of new resorts and inns offers spas, private gardens, fine restaurants and exquisite settings.

item.title: International Oscar Favorites Are Offering a Complicated New View of America
item.content:encoded: The Oscars has become friendlier to non-English language movies. And the movies seem aware of their American audiences.

item.title: Yondr Pouches, a Solution to School Phone Bans, Are No Match for Teens
item.content:encoded: In some schools, Yondr, a pouch marketed to keep kids off devices, has proved no match for actual children.

item.title: Ukraine Wants to Join the E.U. to Secure Peace. Here’s What to Know.
item.content:encoded: Negotiators agree that joining the bloc is critical to Kyiv’s future. But obstacles abound, and compromises might forever change how the union works.

item.title: Can A.I. Detection Tools Really Spot Fake Images and Videos?
item.content:encoded: Artificial intelligence detectors are increasingly used to check the veracity of content online. We ran more than 1,000 tests and found several strengths and plenty of weaknesses.

item.title: How Mamdani Learned From the First Snowstorm and Prepared for the Second
item.content:encoded: As the forecast rapidly worsened, Mayor Zohran Mamdani urged his staff to implement new policies and emphasized the need to communicate aggressively about the snow.

item.title: Mamdani’s New Social Services Chief Worked to Reduce Street Homelessness
item.content:encoded: Mayor Zohran Mamdani selected Erin Dalton, a public official in the Pittsburgh area, to head New York City’s Department of Social Services.

item.title: A New York City Diner That Served Blind Residents Has Closed Its Doors
item.content:encoded: When Malibu Diner in Chelsea shut down on Sunday night, it ended a unique breakfast program for older people in the city.

item.title: Jimmy Kimmel Goes Live After a Super Long State of the Union
item.content:encoded: “I can’t believe America missed an all-new ‘Will Trent’ for this one,” he joked.

item.title: Futsal Phenom in Afghanistan Is a Hero the Taliban Didn’t Expect
item.content:encoded: A triumph in indoor soccer has turned Alireza Ahmadi, 17, and other players from the Hazara minority, long marginalized in Afghanistan, into national heroes.

item.title: Abu Dhabi’s State Oil Company Looks Beyond Oil
item.content:encoded: Having reshaped the company, Sultan Ahmed Al Jaber wants to expand internationally, particularly in natural gas, chemicals and renewables.

item.title: Abu Dhabi’s State Oil Company Looks Beyond Oil
item.content:encoded: Having reshaped the company, Sultan Ahmed Al Jaber wants to expand internationally, particularly in natural gas, chemicals and renewables.

item.title: Pentagon Gives Anthropic an Ultimatum Over the Company’s A.I. Model
item.content:encoded: Anthropic insists on limits on how its technology is used and could be labeled a supply chain risk if it fails to accept the military’s demands.

item.title: Court Rules Against Justice Dept. Search of Reporter’s Computers
item.content:encoded: The judge said the court itself would search the devices, which were seized from a Washington Post reporter’s home last month.

item.title: Court Rules Against Justice Dept. Search of Reporter’s Computers
item.content:encoded: The judge said the court itself would search the devices, which were seized from a Washington Post reporter’s home last month.

item.title: Paramount Raises Its Bid for Warner Bros. Discovery
item.content:encoded: Warner Bros. Discovery said Paramount’s new offer of $31 a share could lead to a “superior proposal” to the deal it signed with Netflix.

item.title: Senator Blumenthal Opens Inquiry Into Iran Transactions on Binance
item.content:encoded: Senator Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut sent a letter to Binance asking about the flow of $1.7 billion from accounts on the crypto exchange to Iranian entities.

item.title: Wayve, an A.I. Driverless Car Start-Up in Europe, Raises $1.2 Billion
item.content:encoded: The London-based company is building a system that uses artificial intelligence to power autonomous vehicles.

item.title: Averted Midair Collision Shows Importance of Air Safety Act, Backers Say
item.content:encoded: The legislation’s advocates say a close call between two private planes near Teterboro, N.J., on Feb. 13 underscored how collision prevention technology could save lives.

item.title: House Narrowly Rejects Air Safety Bill After Pentagon Opposition
item.content:encoded: A move to swiftly pass the bill failed by a single vote. It would have required aircraft to carry technology that officials said might have prevented a midair collision near Washington last year.

item.title: U.K., Australia and Others Worse Off Under Trump’s New Tariffs
item.content:encoded: Many important U.S. trading partners are facing higher duties after President Trump, reacting to a Supreme Court setback, set the rate on a new set of global tariffs at 15 percent.

item.title: Trump’s Tariffs Are Adding Steel Mill Jobs, and Crushing American Factories
item.content:encoded: Tariffs unaffected by President Trump’s Supreme Court loss are adding costs for many U.S. manufacturers that use steel, limiting exports and jeopardizing jobs.

item.title: Trump’s Tariffs Go Into Effect at 10 Percent, Not 15
item.content:encoded: The change surprised executives and foreign leaders, who had been expecting the 15 percent rate the president announced on Saturday.

item.title: Trump’s New Tariffs Could Face Legal Challenges
item.content:encoded: Critics are questioning the legality of the provision President Trump has used to replace his previous slate of tariffs, raising the prospect of yet another legal battle.

item.title: More Than Half of Teens Use Chatbots for Schoolwork, Survey Finds
item.content:encoded: A new study from the Pew Research Center finds teenagers think chatbot-assisted cheating has become “a regular feature of student life.”

item.title: Home Depot Says Homeowners Are Weary From Economic Pressures
item.content:encoded: The retailer said same-store sales were nearly flat as homeowners shied away from big-ticket projects amid worries about housing costs and the job market.

item.title: ‘A.I. Literacy’ Is the New Drivers’ Ed at This Newark School
item.content:encoded: Teachers say they want to equip high school students to drive artificial intelligence, rather than be mere passengers steered by chatbots.

item.title: Racing to Catch Up With Nvidia, AMD Signs Chips-for-Stock Deal With Meta
item.content:encoded: The multibillion-dollar deal is AMD’s latest move to catch up to Nvidia in the lucrative world of selling artificial intelligence chips.

item.title: The Looming Taiwan Chip Disaster That Silicon Valley Has Long Ignored
item.content:encoded: If China invades Taiwan and cuts off its chip exports to American companies, the tech industry and the U.S. economy would be crippled.

item.title: What’s Happened Since the Supreme Court’s Tariff Ruling
item.content:encoded: After the Trump administration’s punishing tariffs were invalidated, the president said he would impose new tariffs using a different authority. It’s been a whirlwind.

item.title: Trump Officials Seek to ‘Reimagine’ Unemployment Benefits, Targeting Fraud
item.content:encoded: Federal officials are subjecting some states to higher scrutiny in an antifraud campaign, as the president rails against California and states led by Democrats.

item.title: Supreme Court Sides With Couple in Case Involving Baby Food Sold at Whole Foods
item.content:encoded: The court agreed to revive a lawsuit by a Texas couple who claimed that tainted baby food purchased at Whole Foods had sickened their young son.

item.title: Paramount Revises Its Bid for Warner Bros. Discovery
item.content:encoded: If Warner Bros. deems Paramount’s latest bid superior, Netflix would have four days to make a counteroffer.

item.title: Storm Leads to a First for The Boston Globe: A Day Without a Paper
item.content:encoded: The company said the blizzard had made it too treacherous for workers to make it to the printing press on Monday.

item.title: After Saks Bankruptcy, Richard Baker Says He Saved Luxury Department Stores
item.content:encoded: Richard Baker wanted to create a retail empire when he combined Saks Fifth Avenue and Neiman Marcus. About a year later, it filed for bankruptcy.

item.title: I.R.S. Tactics Against Meta Open a New Front in the Corporate Tax Fight
item.content:encoded: The agency is using real-world profit data to challenge how big companies value offshore intellectual property.

item.title: FedEx Sues for Refund of Trump Tariffs Rejected by Supreme Court
item.content:encoded: The company, which did not specify how much it was seeking, is expected to be one of many demanding compensation for levies ruled unlawful.

item.title: Pentagon Summons Anthropic Chief in Dispute Over A.I. Limits
item.content:encoded: The artificial intelligence company has demanded that some guardrails be put in place as it negotiates a contract with the Defense Department.

item.title: Trump Administration Scrambles to Pick Up the Pieces of Broken Tariffs
item.content:encoded: President Trump is already working to piece his tariff program back together, after a Supreme Court ruling ruptured a centerpiece of his economic agenda.

item.title: Thousands of Flights Are Canceled as Storm Slams Northeast Airports
item.content:encoded: Airlines suspended operations at some major airports and expect to restart some flights on Monday and more on Tuesday.

item.title: Supreme Court Considers Fate of Docks and Other Assets Seized by Cuba in 1960
item.content:encoded: Amid rising tensions with Cuba, the Trump administration is backing lawsuits that would allow Americans to get compensation for property confiscated by Fidel Castro’s regime.

item.title: Binance Employees Find $1.7 Billion in Crypto Was Sent to Iranian Entities
item.content:encoded: Binance pledged to crack down on crime. But internal investigators at the world’s largest crypto exchange continued to find evidence of potential legal violations on the platform.

item.title: Top Fed Official Sees Little Effect on Rate Outlook From Supreme Court’s Tariff Ruling
item.content:encoded: Christopher J. Waller, a Federal Reserve governor, said he would support a pause in rate cuts in March if the labor market continued to show signs of stabilizing.

item.title: More Than Half a Million Customers Have Lost Power on East Coast
item.content:encoded: The outages were mostly caused by problems with local power lines, and coastal Massachusetts was particularly hard hit.

item.title: From Sundance Director to Head of Film Forum
item.content:encoded: Tabitha Jackson sees an opportunity to develop the next generation of cinephiles at the Greenwich Village art-house cinema.

item.title: Tariff Turmoil Returns to Global Markets
item.content:encoded: Businesses and U.S. trade partners are again grappling with the uncertainty of President Trump’s trade war, even as he imposes new levies.

item.title: Fact-Check: Trump’s Latest Claims on Jobs, Inflation and Crime
item.content:encoded: Trends on jobs, inflation and crime that began before Donald Trump retook office continued, largely unabated, in his first year back.

item.title: Homeownership Is Out of Reach for Many Americans, Despite a Buyer’s Market
item.content:encoded: A growing split between low-to-middle-income families and wealthy households is changing who has access to homeownership now.

item.title: ‘A.I. Literacy’ Is Trending in Schools. Here’s Why.
item.content:encoded: Artificial intelligence companies are urging teachers to prepare students for an “A.I.-driven future.” What that means varies from school to school.

item.title: Need an Outfit? Pickle Clothing Rental App Helps Users Stay on Trend.
item.content:encoded: Pickle, a new peer-to-peer apparel-rental app, helps users stay on trend without having to go into debt or rely on climate-unfriendly fast fashion.

item.title: Trump Aides Project Confidence on Tariffs After Court Loss
item.content:encoded: Administration officials maintain that they can replicate the sky-high duties recently invalidated by the Supreme Court.

item.title: They Did Deals With Trump to Get Lower Tariffs. Now They Are Stuck.
item.content:encoded: Countries that under the threat of tariffs made commitments like enormous investment pledges face the reality that they might have been better off waiting.

item.title: Trump Calls on Netflix to Oust Susan Rice From Its Board
item.content:encoded: The president made the attack as Netflix and Paramount Skydance face a key deadline in a bidding war for Warner Bros. Discovery.

item.title: Should I Tell My Housekeeper, ‘I’m Here for You’?
item.content:encoded: Plus, what to do when your job interviewer spouts off on things better left unsaid.

item.title: Trump’s Challenge to Free Market Capitalism
item.content:encoded: Stakes in private companies. Handshake deals with chief executives. The president’s economic policy has drifted far from principles that long defined the Republican Party. Is it capitalism at all?

item.title: A Roving Reporter on the Future of Transit in New York City
item.content:encoded: “A lot of interesting things happening in the city involve how people get around,” said Stefanos Chen, a Metro reporter and lifelong bus aficionado.

item.title: How The Times Handles the Congressional Hearing Circus
item.content:encoded: Three editors in Washington discuss their approach to coverage of politicians and witnesses who sometimes seem to be performing for the cameras.
